content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, my strategy would be to consider this as a repeated game where both players have an incentive to cooperate (choose R) in each round for the maximum payoff of 45$. However, since the game is repeated 75 times, there is also an opportunity for players to exploit each other by deviating from cooperation and switching strategies to maximize individual earnings.

Given that I don't know the strategy of my anonymous opponent, I might start by choosing R to show a cooperative attitude. If the opponent follows with R as well, then I can expect 45$ per round for 75 rounds, which is a total of (45 * 75 =) 3375$.

If my opponent chooses B in response to my initial R, they will get 42$ while I get nothing. In this case, it would make sense to switch strategies and choose B from now on, as I can expect 12$ per round for 75 rounds, which is a total of (12 * 75 =) 900$.

If I choose R in response to my opponent's initial B, I will get 42$, while they get nothing. In this case, it would make sense to switch strategies and choose B from now on, as I can expect 12$ per round for 75 rounds, which is a total of (12 * 75 =) 900$.

In conclusion, the optimal strategy for me would be to start with R to show a cooperative attitude. However, if my opponent chooses B in response, I should switch strategies and choose B from now on to maximize my earnings over the long run. If they stick with R after my initial B, I should switch back to R to maximize my earnings.

You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

In this case, my opponent showed that they are willing to exploit me by choosing B when I initially chose R. To maximize my earnings over the long run in this repeated game, I should switch strategies and choose B for the next round.
